title: 114_hr5594
content: The Act is titled the "National Strategy for Combating Terrorist, Underground, and Other Illicit Financing Act". The Congress recognizes the direct threat of terrorism financing to national security and global stability. Terrorist groups constantly evolve, forming new threats and adapting tactics. Some terrorists have symbiotic relationships with transnational crime syndicates, blurring the lines between funding for terrorism and criminal profits. Rapid changes in methods of concealing illicit funding pose new risks for governments to detect and prevent terrorism financing. The bipartisan requirement for a national anti-money laundering strategy expired in 2007, highlighting the need for an updated strategy focused on terrorism financing. It is crucial for the Government to have a unified and annually updated strategy to combat financial crime effectively. An updated strategy to combat financial crime, including terrorism financing, is crucial for the United States and should be revised annually to address evolving threats and assist Congress in setting priorities. The development of a national strategy is essential for combating financial crime and terrorism financing, with annual revisions to address evolving threats and assist Congress in setting priorities. The President, with the Secretary of the Treasury, will develop a national strategy to combat terrorism financing and illicit finance, in consultation with various agencies. The strategy must be submitted to Congress annually by June 1, along with a report on the effectiveness of existing efforts and broader strategies. The national strategy to combat terrorism financing and illicit finance includes addressing high-risk areas, evaluating the effectiveness of efforts, and integrating the strategy into the broader counter-terrorism strategy of the United States. Classified information will be presented separately. Classified information related to the national strategy on combating terrorism financing will be submitted to Congress separately in a classified annex or as a briefing upon request by the appropriate congressional committee members. SEC. 4. CONTENTS. The strategy outlined in section 3 must include a comprehensive discussion of threats, goals, objectives, and priorities for combating illicit finance in the US and abroad. It should also address coordination with international, State, and local entities, as well as reviews of enforcement efforts and proposed changes to relevant regulations and laws. The strategy must include discussions of proposed changes to ensure coordinated efforts in combating illicit finance. Efforts to improve detection and prosecution of illicit finance, including data sharing among government agencies and financial institutions, are also highlighted. The private financial sector plays a crucial role in preventing illicit finance by enhancing partnerships with federal agencies to detect and prevent money laundering. Efforts include facilitating compliance with laws while maintaining effectiveness. Enhancing intergovernmental cooperation to combat illicit finance by strengthening partnerships between federal, state, and local officials, as well as promoting international cooperation among governments. The curr_chunk focuses on the 3-year projection for program and budget priorities to reduce illicit finance, assessment of funding adequacy, and trend analysis with a special focus on terrorism financing. The curr_chunk discusses the enforcement of policies to combat illicit finance, including the Treasury attaches' effectiveness in fighting against illicit finance at various embassies. The curr_chunk discusses the assignment of Treasury attaches for temporary duty, handling of economic and anti-terror finance issues at embassies, and the impact of not having more attaches in vulnerable embassies. The curr_chunk focuses on combating illicit finance and cyber crime through discussions on terrorist financing, evolving technology, and leveraging big data analytics to enhance effectiveness in the fight against terror financing. The curr_chunk focuses on defining key terms related to combating illicit finance and cyber crime. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to combating illicit finance and cyber crime, including "appropriate congressional committees," "appropriate Federal banking agencies," and the "Bank Secrecy Act." The Bank Secrecy Act includes specific sections of various laws. Illicit finance refers to funding terrorism, money laundering, and other illegal financial activities. The term "State" encompasses states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. The Bank Secrecy Act includes specific sections of various laws and addresses illicit finance. Passed by the House of Representatives on July 11, 2016.
